course.name: Empty-Shell-Course-05
course.title: Antechamber Delivery - Attempter Intro
course.description: This course teaches you to train an AI by guiding it through complex conversational tasks. You will learn to craft detailed scenarios, challenge the model by acting as a "lazy user," and provide precise corrections and critiques to improve its reasoning and tool use.

contents.body:
Welcome to the Antechamber Delivery!


Your mission is to train an advanced AI by guiding it through multi-step tasks. Think of yourself as a collaborator, not just a tester. You will teach the model how to behave and respond in various situations.


Your main goals are to ensure the AI:


  • Adheres to your Complex System Prompt
  • Responds to your Lazy User Prompt correctly
  • Chooses the correct tools to solve problems.
  • Uses the tools correctly.
  • Receives feedback/revisions re: wrong tool call / unpreferred responses.
  • Responds naturally, like a real assistant

Here are some useful resources for this project:


  • Project Instructions – Read them after going through the course!

Every task you do begins here. The System Prompt sets the stage and defines the rules of engagement for the specific scenario you are about to create.


Think of it as a custom-made personality and instruction manual for the AI, which only applies to the current task. The AI's performance throughout the entire conversation will be judged on how well it follows these rules.


To create a unique and complex System Prompt, blend at least 4 of the following elements:


  • Agent's Environment: Its current location, time, or device settings (e.g., WiFi is off). Make sure the environment settings match the system settings.
  • Rules for Tools: Specific instructions on how to use tools (e.g., "Always confirm before deleting an event").
  • User's Likes & Dislikes: The user's preferences, habits, or pet peeves.
  • User's Situation: Important background information (e.g., "The user is sleep-deprived and needs simple options").
  • Agent's Personality: The desired tone and speaking style (e.g., professional, witty, concise).


Goal: Write a detailed prompt that establishes a clear, consistent context. This "master prompt" will govern the AI's behavior for the entire task that follows.


You will write this in the designated "System Prompt" field at the top of the task.


Example


"You are a professional and friendly assistant, dedicated to being proactive and helpful. Your user is currently planning a last-minute business trip to San Francisco and is feeling quite stressed about it. The user has some clear preferences: they always want a window seat on flights and are a strict vegetarian. Please be aware that the user's device is low on battery. For this reason, if a setting needs to be changed, you must suggest the user do it themselves rather than using a tool. Always confirm final details before making any bookings."


  • Personality: You are a professional and friendly assistant...
  • User's Situation: ...planning a last-minute business trip to San Francisco and is feeling quite stressed...
  • User Preferences: ...they always want a window seat on flights and are a strict vegetarian...
  • Agent's Environment: ...user's device is low on battery...
  • Rules for Tools: ...if a setting needs to be changed, you must suggest the user do it themselves…



Note:

  1. System prompts will have guardrails to reach a minimum length / required complexity.
  2. System Prompts should not be repeated - re-use of system prompts can result in account deactivation. This behavior is strictly forbidden.

After setting the stage with the System Prompt, your next step is to initiate the conversation. You'll input this first prompt into the 'Turn #1 - Prompt' field. For this project, you will always adopt a specific persona: the "Lazy User."



The goal of the "Lazy User" is to test the AI's ability to ask good clarifying questions and handle ambiguity.


Your prompts must follow these rules:


  • Start Vague: Your first prompt should be underspecified (e.g., "I need a reservation").
  • Don't Volunteer Information: Only provide details when the AI explicitly asks for them. (one answer at a time.)
  • One Piece at a Time: If the AI asks multiple questions, only answer one of them in your response.
  • Correct Mistakes: If the AI makes a wrong assumption, your next prompt should correct it.


Keep in mind:


  • Be Natural: Your prompts should sound like something a real person would say.
  • Focus on the Goal, Not the Tool: Ask for what you want (e.g., "Find cafes near me"), not how to do it (e.g., "Use the search tool for cafes").


Example


You (User): "I need to make a reservation."


AI (potential response): "I can help with that. What kind of reservation is it, and for what date and time?"


You (User): "For a restaurant."

Understanding Task Categories


  • Categories for User prompts: Understanding task categories helps you determine what type of interaction you need to generate. Some tasks require the model to use tools, while others should be answered without tool use.
  • [Feasible Tool Use]: If the user's request can be fulfilled by the available tools, your prompts should guide the agent towards successfully completing the task using those tools. The agent should try to achieve tasks by itself when possible, without unnecessarily asking the user for information it can derive (e.g., current location).
  • Example: User: "Find Italian restaurants near me." (Agent should get current location, search for Italian restaurants). 
  • [Infeasible Tool Use]: If a request cannot be fulfilled with the provided tools, guide the agent to gracefully fail by clearly explaining the attempts made and the reason for failure.
  • Example: User: "Does Nola Restaurant accept Apple Pay?" (Agent may search for Nola, get details, but if payment info isn't available via tools, it should state that and suggest alternatives like calling the restaurant). 
  • [General Chat]: Include user tasks that are general chat questions, not intended to be solved by tools, but could be mistaken for tool-use tasks by an underperforming agent. The agent should answer these without invoking tools.
  • Example: User: "What color is the Golden Gate Bridge?" Agent should directly answer "International orange...
  • [State Dependency]: Design scenarios where tool errors occur due to the state of the initial database (e.g., WiFi is off, low battery mode is on). Your dialogue should then guide the agent to identify and recover from these errors by modifying the state (e.g., turning WiFi on).
  • Example: User asks to search for a place. Initial DB has WiFi off. Agent tries to search, gets a "WiFi not enabled" error. Agent then checks settings, sees WiFi is off. Tries to turn WiFi on, but fails if "low_battery_mode" is on. Agent then turns off low battery mode, then turns on WiFi, then successfully performs the search. 
  • [Error Recovery]: Create situations where the agent uses a tool incorrectly (e.g., wrong parameters, too specific query yielding no results). Crucially, do not correct the agent in its first attempt. Instead, your subsequent user prompts should guide the agent to refine its tool call and recover from its own mistake.
  • Example: User: "What is my next one on one?" Agent searches calendar but misses datetime_range_upperbound, gets an error. In the next turn, you guide it (e.g., by a user prompt like "Search for the next year") so the agent re-tries the tool call correctly. If it still fails (e.g. searches "one on one" but event is "1:1"), guide it again (e.g., User: "It might be named differently, and it's with Jill") for the agent to try a broader search or different parameters. 
  • [Lazy User]: Model the user as "lazy." The user should:
  • Not provide information unless explicitly asked by the assistant.
  • Provide only one piece of information at a time, even if asked multiple questions.
  • Correct the assistant if it makes wrong assumptions.
  • Start with underspecified requests.
  • Example: User: "I need a reservation." Assistant: "What type, location, date, etc.?" User: "Restaurant." 
  • [Task Switching]: Create scenarios where the user naturally deviates from the current task to ask something else (a detour), and then switches back to the original task after the detour is complete.
  • ﻿Example: User: "Add an event at 5 tomorrow." Agent clarifies AM/PM, asks for calendar. User: "Wait, do I have my WiFi on?" Agent checks WiFi, responds. User: "K, add the event to my personal calendar."

After you submit your prompt, the AI will respond. It might try to use a tool, ask a question, or give a direct answer. Your job is to supervise this action. Bear in mind the tool set for each task. The model only has access to a specific set of tools within each task.


In the task interface, every AI response will appear with a "Refine your response" section. This is where you step in. If the AI’s action isn't perfect, you will use this section to edit its response and show it the ideal action it should have taken.


﻿


How you guide the model:


  • If the AI uses a tool incorrectly: You will see the tool it chose and the parameters it used. You can change the tool from a dropdown list or edit the parameters (like a search query or location) to be correct.


  • If the AI gives text but should have used a tool: You can change the response type from "text" to "tool call" and then select the correct tool and parameters it missed.


  • If the AI's text response is flawed: You can directly edit or completely rewrite the text in the response box to make it more accurate, helpful, or aligned with its persona.


This editing step is how you "provide the ideal response." The conversation then continues as if the AI had performed your corrected action from the start.

After you correct the AI's action, you must explain why its original attempt was wrong. This is the most important step for training the model.


For every action the AI takes, you will provide feedback using two fields:


1. Error Labels: Choose one or more predefined tags from a list to categorize the mistake.


  • Examples: wrong_tool_selected, required_param_missing, tool_over_triggered.
  • If the AI's original action was perfect, select no_issues.


2. Critic Comments: Write a clear, concise explanation of the error. If there was no error, you can leave this blank.


Note: Critic Comments MUST follow the following guidelines:


  • It should be specific about the issues. e.g. Instead of saying “Wrong tool is chosen”, you should say “Tool photos_open_destination is not the correct tool to use. The model should use photos_open_album instead”.
  • Always reference tool names and parameter names/values whenever possible.
  • All Tool Names and Parameters must be enclosed in backticks `example`
  • All values must be enclosed in double quotes “value example”
  • YOU MUST refer to specific tools and parameters where applicable and enclose names in ' ' backticks




Example


Original AI Action: The AI used the search_place tool with the query parameter set to "dinner".


Your Correction: You edited the query to be "Italian restaurants near me".


Your Critique:


  • Error Label: wrong_param_value
  • Critic Comment: The query parameter value was too vague. It should have been "Italian restaurants near me" to fulfill the user's request.

Your ultimate goal is to create a complete, natural-feeling conversation with at least 10 user turns.


A "user turn" is counted each time you, playing the "Lazy User," provide a new prompt. The AI's responses, tool calls, and clarifying questions do not count toward this total.


To reach 10 turns, you will continue the cycle:


  1. Write a User Prompt (following the "Lazy User" rules).
  2. Guide the AI by editing its response if needed.
  3. Provide a Critique with error labels and comments.
  4. Repeat.


How to create a meaningful conversation:


  • Flow Naturally: Your follow-up prompts should logically build on the previous turns.
  • Mix It Up: A good scenario might include clarifying questions, chained tool calls (where one tool's output is used by another), or parallel calls (multiple tools used at once).
  • Introduce Complexity: You can create more advanced scenarios that involve:
  • Task Switching: Briefly ask about something else before returning to the original task.
  • Error Recovery: Guide the AI to fix a mistake it made on a previous turn.
  • Infeasible Tasks: Ask for something the tools can't do, and teach the AI to explain the limitation gracefully.

contents.question: What is the main goal of an Antechamber conversation?

choices.answer: Entertain the user
Teach the model correct tool use & recovery
Repeat the user verbatim
Gather user data

contents.question: How many user turns must each conversation contain at minimum?
In a General Chat task, the assistant should…

choices.answer: Call search_place proactively
Answer with text only unless the user explicitly asks for a tool
Add everything to the user’s calendar
Refuse to answer

contents.question: A user asks: “Book lunch near me at 1 pm.” The agent calls search_place without first getting the user’s location; which error label fits?

choices.answer: no_issues
wrong_tool_selected
required_param_missing
hallucinated_tool

contents.question: For a single assistant turn that both omits a required parameter and uses a value outside the allowed enum list, how should the annotator fill error_labels and critic_comments?

choices.answer:
error_labels: required_param_missing

critic_comments: "Wrong enum value."

error_labels: enum_not_respected, required_param_missing

critic_comments: "Missing parameter."

error_labels: required_param_missing, enum_not_respected

critic_comments: "Tool call did not provide the mandatory latitude parameter. The value of travel_mode is not in the allowed enum list."

error_labels: others

critic_comments: "Multiple problems."

contents.question:
In Error Recovery tasks, what is the supervisor’s first step when the agent’s tool call has a bad enum value?


Hint: The agent must self‑correct later.

choices.answer: Fix the call yourself
Tag the error, leave a critic comment, do not correct yet
End the dialogue
Skip the turn

contents.question:
What new category tests device state like Wi‑Fi OFF → toggle ON?


Hint: State causes the first failure.

choices.answer: Task‑Switching
State‑Dependency
Feasible Tool
Use Calendar DB

contents.question:
The assistant calls search_calendar_events includes a parameter calendar_slug="Personal", but the tool definition for search_calendar_events does not include any calendar_slug argument. Which error label should be applied?

Hint: The assistant used a parameter that doesn’t exist in the schema.

choices.answer: required_param_missing
enum_not_respected
param_not_defined
wrong_param_value

contents.question:
Why must every task have a unique system prompt?

Hint: Variety strengthens training.

choices.answer: Easier to copy‑paste
Prevents the model from memorising patterns
Saves storage
Required for JSON size

contents.question: Can my account get deactivated for repeating system prompts (Yes it can)

choices.answer: Yes, I understand that if I use the same system prompt twice I can get banned from Outlier
No, I can reuse system prompts

contents.question:
Select the agent response that best fulfils the instructions. The correct option is never number 1.

Scenario 1 – Feasible Tool Use

User: “Find a vegetarian café within walking distance and add it to my calendar at 4 pm tomorrow.”


﻿Hint: Proper chain of tools + confirmation.

choices.answer: Option 1: Explains three cafés, no tool calls.
Option 2: Calls search_place → lists café, then asks user to add manually.
Option 3: Calls search_place, selects top café, confirms time and calendar, then create_calendar_event for 4 pm tomorrow.
Option 4: Refuses, saying dietary needs are unclear.

contents.question:
Scenario 2 – Infeasible Tool Use

User: “Tell me the live score of my village cricket match.”

﻿Hint: Graceful fail—no hallucination.

choices.answer: Option 1: Calls search_place with the village name.
Option 2 : Responds text‑only that no such API data exists and suggests local sources.
Option 3: Makes up a score.
Option 4: Adds a calendar event called “Cricket.”

contents.question:
Scenario 3 – Error Recovery

User: “When’s my next dentist appointment?” The agent’s first tool call omits datetime_range_upperbound → API error.

Hint: Nudge, don’t patch.

choices.answer: Option 1: Fix the JSON immediately.
Option 2: End the task.
Option 3 : Prompt: “Maybe check the next few months?” so the agent retries; tag required_param_missing.
Option 4: Ignore and continue.

contents.question:
Scenario 4 – State Dependency

System prompt says Wi‑Fi = OFF.

User: “Give me transit directions to the airport.”


Hint: Fix state before net‑dependent call.

choices.answer: Option 1: Calls get_directions and fails.
Option 2: Refuses.
Option 3 : Turns Wi‑Fi ON via set_system_settings, then calls get_directions.
Option 4: Asks the user to turn on data.

contents.question:
Scenario 5 – Task Switching

User: “Add a birthday reminder for Mum next Thursday… actually, is my Bluetooth on?”


Hint: Handle detour then finish original ask.

choices.answer: Option 1: Asks to clarify which task first.
Option 2 : Checks Bluetooth with get_system_settings, answers, then resumes and create_calendar_event for birthday.
Option 3: Ignores Bluetooth question, adds event only.
Option 4: Turns on Wi‑Fi.

contents.body: Congratulations! You've completed the introductory course. Next, please review our Project Instructions—there are important details you'll need before you can begin contributing to the project.
